awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evolutionary tradeoffs between outcross siring success and selfing: the role of ecological context in the stability of mixed mating systems
awd_abstract_narration:
A major unsolved question in biology is why plant populations often maintain a mixture of two reproductive strategies, self-fertilization and cross-pollination. Long standing genetic theories predict that these should rarely co-exist. Yet this dual strategy is surprisingly common in nature, suggesting that existing theory is inadequate. This project tests the hypothesis that ecological interactions among plant species help maintain dual strategies. When multiple plant species flower together and share pollinators, pollen is often wasted on flowers of other species, reducing the benefits of cross-pollination. The researchers will evaluate this hypothesis through a combination of theory development, field studies of pollinator behavior, and molecular genetic studies of parentage. This research will enhance conservation of plant and pollinator communities and will help scientists understand how invasive species and habitat fragmentation influence pollination. A partnership with an economically-disadvantaged K-12 school will foster improved understanding of conservation and biodiversity. 

Focusing on the perennial plant Mimulus ringens, empirical and theoretical studies will investigate how pollinator sharing affects the tradeoff between outcross siring and selfing. Manipulative experiments will evaluate whether changes in the ecological context, the abundance of a co-flowering species Lobelia siphilitica, influence patterns of natural selection on selfing. Comparisons of 32 natural populations that vary in the type and abundance of co-flowering species will provide information on selfing rates, pollen limitation, floral morphology, and inbreeding depression, and evolutionary responses. Models will be developed using an adaptive dynamics approach that will incorporate the automatic advantage of selfing, evolutionary changes in inbreeding depression; it will account for pollen loss caused by the presence of a co-flowering species, and will explore the range of genetic and ecological factors that could generate stabilizing selection on mixed mating. These linked empirical and theoretical investigations will provide a broad new framework for understanding the evolution of plant mating systems.

por.por_cntn:
Collaborative Research: Evolutionary tradeoffs between outcross siring success and selfing: the role of ecological context in the stability of mixed mating systems

 

Intellectual Merit:

Most flowering plants depend on foraging animals for cross-pollination. A pollinator visiting a focal flower can deposit pollen grains from other plants onto female reproductive organs, leading to seed production. Then, as the pollinator departs the flower, it may transport pollen to other plants, promoting the plant’s success in fathering offspring. However, these pollinator foraging movements may also cause self-pollination, deposition of a plant’s own pollen onto its female reproductive structures. Seeds resulting from self-fertilization are often less likely to survive than seeds produced through cross-fertilization. Yet when pollinators are scarce or unreliable, self-fertilization may provide reproductive assurance. Although rates of self-fertilization were once thought to be characteristic of different flowering plant species, an increasing number of studies have shown wide variation in the extent of self-fertilization within and among populations of individual species.  The causes of this variation are poorly understood. This project combined molecular genetic tools with field studies of natural and experimental populations to explore the ecological and genetic factors influencing variation in mating patterns within and among populations of monkeyflower (Mimulus ringens).

Self-fertilization rates varied widely among natural populations of Mimulus ringens (13%– 55%) and increased strongly and significantly with floral display (the number of flowers open simultaneously on a plant). Pollinators often visit more flowers sequentially on larger displays, providing one explanation for the increase in rates of self-fertilization with display.  Self-fertilization also increased in sites with low pollinator visitation and low plant density, highlighting the importance of ecological context in variation in mating patterns. In many populations, Mimulus ringens was pollinated primarily by large bees (Bombus, Apis, Anthophora), and their pollination caused the stigmas (female reproductive structure) of the flowers to close by mid-morning, ending further pollination. However, at sites where large bees are scarce, stigmas were often open past noon because of the reduced pollination. In these conditions, small bees (only active during the warmer conditions of late mornings) had the opportunity to pollinate. However, these smaller bees deposit and remove less pollen, and may be less effective at cross-fertilization, and therefore provide inferior pollination services compared to large bees.

Detailed analyses of paternity in experimental populations of this hermaphroditic plant revealed significantly greater among-individual variation in male reproductive success than for female reproductive success, providing a rare confirmation of an important tenet of reproductive theory. Furthermore, male reproductive success increased strongly with mate number per plant, suggesting that male reproductive success was limited by mating opportunities. By contrast, female reproductive success did not change with mate number, suggesting that resources may be a more important constraint than opportunity, and that the factors that influence male and female reproductive success may substantially differ.

Research on mate diversity in flowering plants has largely focused on the number of fathers siring seeds within fruits. Yet each hermaphroditic flower also contributes to mate diversity by fathering seeds on other plants. We quantified mating portfolios of individual flowers, and showed that dual sex roles in this hermaphroditic plant contribute to a near doubling of mate diversity.  Such an increase in mating options increases the opportunities for mate choice and mate competition to influence the reproductive biology of this and other plants.

These findings enhance understanding of the factors affecting conservation of biodiversity. Further declines in pollinator abundance and changes in plant species composition in natural communities may increase rates of self-fertilization, leading to lower seed viability or establishment success.  Declines in pollinator visitation may also influence mate diversity for plants, thereby affecting the genetic structure of populations and the resilience of populations to environmental change.

Broader Impacts:

This award supported the training of a diverse team of students and early career professionals including 35 undergraduate students, 7 graduate students, 1 postdoctoral scholar, and 1 K-12 teacher.  The majority of this research team were women.

The research team presented 17 talks at national and international meetings of professional societies, including the Botanical Society of America, The Ecological Society of America, and the Society for the Study of Evolution.  The PIs also presented more than 30 public presentations describing findings from this research.


This and related research about ecology, plants, wetlands, and biomimicry were shared with more than 13,000 K-12 students in both field trips and classroom visits via the University of Akron Field Station.
